information_requirement: Is an adversary exfiltrating data from mobile devices over an established command and control (C2) channel? (PIR)

evidence.description: A single outbound connection from a mobile device shows an anomalously high data volume or connection duration, or the total daily outbound data volume to a specific destination exceeds the 99th percentile of the device's 30-day historical baseline for that destination. This activity is often observed over non-standard ports or uses TLS fingerprinting common to malware.
evidence.nai: Network gateways for corporate Wi-Fi, VPN concentrators, Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) egress points, and other network egress points monitoring mobile device traffic.
action: Query Zeek conn.log for connections from the mobile IP range where the destination IP is present on a C2 threat intelligence feed. Correlate with Zeek ssl.log and alert if the JA3 hash is on a watchlist of known malicious clients. Separately, search conn.log for sessions where outbound bytes (orig_bytes) exceed a static threshold (e.g., 25MB) to a single destination in a single connection.

For each unique source mobile IP (id.orig_h), establish a 30-day rolling baseline of outbound bytes (orig_bytes) and connection duration per destination IP (id.resp_h). Calculate the 99th percentile for both metrics. Generate an alert when a new connection's orig_bytes or duration exceeds its respective percentile threshold for that source-destination pair.

Implement a time series forecasting model (e.g., Prophet, ARIMA) for the aggregate daily outbound data volume (SUM of orig_bytes) for each mobile device-to-destination pair. Train the model on at least 90 days of Zeek conn.log history. Trigger an alert if the observed daily volume for a given pair exceeds the model's predicted 95% confidence interval, indicating a statistically significant deviation from the established communication pattern.

evidence.description: For HTTP/S traffic from a mobile device to a single web server, the ratio of outbound POST/PUT requests to GET requests is abnormally high (e.g., > 10:1), and the average POST request body size is greater than the 95th percentile of its historical baseline for that destination. The Content-Type header may also be non-standard or generic (e.g., application/octet-stream).
evidence.nai: Internet-facing web proxies, DNS resolvers used by mobile devices, and Unified Endpoint Management (UEM) proxy logs.
action: Using Zeek dns.log, identify mobile devices querying for domains on C2 blocklists or domains with high-entropy names. Correlate the source IP with Zeek http.log and flag any subsequent HTTP POST/PUT requests to those domains where request_body_len exceeds a static threshold (e.g., 1MB). Additionally, alert on the use of known malicious User-Agent strings from a watchlist or where the Content-Type is 'application/octet-stream' and the destination is not an approved file-sharing service.

For each source mobile IP (id.orig_h) and destination host (host) pair in Zeek http.log, calculate a 30-day baseline for the ratio of HTTP POST to GET requests. Separately, establish the baseline average and standard deviation for the POST request body length (request_body_len). Alert when the daily POST:GET ratio exceeds a high threshold (e.g., 10:1) or when the average request_body_len for a 24-hour period exceeds the baseline by more than 3 standard deviations.

Apply an unsupervised clustering algorithm (e.g., DBSCAN) to hourly aggregated HTTP session data. Engineer features per source-destination pair from Zeek http.log, including: request/response size ratio, POST/GET method ratio, user-agent string entropy, URI path entropy, and the distribution of Content-Type headers. Investigate clusters identified as outliers, as they represent network behaviors that deviate significantly from the norm.

evidence.description: Data payloads within a non-TLS/SSL network flow from a mobile device to a low-reputation destination consistently exhibit a Shannon entropy score above 7.5, suggesting the traffic is compressed or custom encrypted.
evidence.nai: Network TAPs capturing traffic from mobile subnets, Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) traffic mirroring, and Wi-Fi access points configured for full packet capture.
action: Monitor Zeek files.log for files extracted from mobile device traffic over unencrypted protocols (e.g., HTTP, FTP). Correlate the connection UID (conn_uids) to Zeek conn.log to identify the destination. Alert if the file's mime_type is an archive format (e.g., 'application/zip', 'application/x-rar-compressed') and the destination IP (id.resp_h) is not on an allow-list of approved corporate cloud services.

Using a Zeek script to analyze payloads in real-time, calculate the Shannon entropy for unencrypted TCP/UDP flows originating from mobile devices to destinations not on an enterprise allow-list. Establish a baseline entropy score for known-good application traffic (e.g., normal HTTP). Alert when a flow's calculated entropy consistently exceeds a high-water mark (e.g., > 7.5 for English text), which is indicative of non-standard encryption or data compression.

Train a binary classification model (e.g., Random Forest, Gradient Boosting) to label network flows as 'benign' or 'potential exfiltration'. Use features from connection metadata (conn.log) and payload analysis, including: payload entropy, protocol, destination port, connection duration, orig_bytes, resp_bytes, packet size distribution statistics (mean, stdev, variance), and a binary flag indicating if the destination IP is on a threat intelligence list. Deploy the model to classify live traffic and generate high-confidence alerts for flows predicted as 'potential exfiltration'.
